perform ihe duties imposed on me with fidelity,
and all the ability I can command. The subject
which assembles you together is one of great importance, not only to the city, but to the state ol
Louisiana and the whole Southwest. I trust, gentlemen, in view of its importance, that you have come
here to act, act, act! A few months ago I had the
honor to be a member of a Convention which assembled at Memphis, for the purpose of constructing a
railroad from the valley of the Mississippi to the
Pacific ocean. That road has not yet been started,
and this state and city have now au opportunity of
laying the first rails of this great road, by carrying
through the great enterprise which it is the object
of this Convention to further and promote. Let us
then, gentlemen, cooperate in this great enterprise
with ardor, enthusiasm, and determination. Let us,
too, after having performed the duties for which we
are convened, go homo to our constituents and urge
thorn to action on this subject. Let us bestow our
votes on no candidates for office, who arc not committed in favor ot this enterprise. Gentlemen, 1
trust your proceedings will be harmonious and satisfactory.
M. M. Cohen then offered the following resolutions :
Resolved, That a railroad shall be built from New Oilcans
